metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Emerging New Concepts of Degrader Technologies Emerging New Concepts of Degrader Technologies

affiliation.laboratory: State Key Laboratory of Medical Neurobiology
Key Laboratory of Micro and Nano Photonic Structures (Ministry of Education)
State Key Laboratory of Medical Neurobiology

abstract.text: Journal Pre-proof J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f 2 / 23

The traditional drug discovery focuses on identifying direct inhibitors of target proteins. This approach typically relies on a specific measurable biochemical readout and amenable binding sites of which the occupancy directly influences the target protein's function. These requirements preclude many disease-causing proteins from being "druggable" targets, and these proteins are categorized as "undruggable". The proteolysis-targeting chimera (PROTAC) technology provides powerful tools to degrade these "undruggable" targets and has become a promising approach for drug discovery. However, the PROTAC technology may have limitations and emerging new degrader technologies may greatly broaden the spectrum of targets that could be selectively degraded by harnessing another major degradation pathway in cells. Here we review a few key emerging technologies that exploit the lysosomal degradation pathway and discuss their potential applications as well as limitations.
Journal Pre-proof J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f 3 / 23

body_text.text: J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f

Cullin-F box complex, leading to ubiquitination and degradation of MetAP-2 in a dose-dependent manner. However, the MetAP-2 covalently-bound moiety was a peptide, hindering the further application towards therapeutic research due to its large molecule size that leads to poor cellular penetration. In 2008, a cell-permeable PROTAC molecule linking the non-steroidal androgen receptor ligand (SARM) and the MDM2 ligand nutlin with a PEG-based linker was synthesized [19] . This PROTAC molecule can induce the ubiquitination of the androgen receptor and its subsequent degradation by the proteasome. This PROTAC system is based on MDM2, which is the major E3 ligase ubiquitinating the tumor suppressor protein p53 [20] . The nutlins family consists of small molecules that bind to the p53-binding pocket of MDM2 and thus competitively inhibit the interaction between p53 and MDM2 [21] , inducing possible off-target effects. The nutlins was further improved to RG7112 [22] and RG7388 [23] , with superior potency and selectivity. In 2010, a new PROTAC system using the cellular inhibitor of apoptosis protein 1 (cIAP1) ubiquitin ligase was established. Hashimoto and colleagues verified that the hybrid molecule coupling the cIAP1 ligand methyl bestatin and the ligand of CRABPs can induce degradation of CRABP-II in cells via the proteasomal pathway [24] . In 2015, the Bradner group has first established another important PROTAC system based on cereblon (CRBN) [25] . CRBN was initially identified as the primary mediator of the teratogenic activity of thalidomide by Handa and colleagues [26] . The immunomodulatory drugs (IMiDs) including thalidomide and its derivatives such as lenalidomide and pomalidomide were later on utilized to treat multiple myeloma [27] . These IMiDs were further reported to interact with the CRBN-DNA damage binding protein-1 (DDB1) complex [28] . Shortly after, a series of PROTAC molecules consist of CRBN-binding IMiD connected with small-molecule ligands of different POIs were designed and their degrader capability was verified [25, 29, 30] . For example, the JQ1-penalidomide chimeric compounds can selectively degrade the BRD4 protein via CRBN [25] . Another PROTAC system, the VHL-PROTAC system based on HIF1-α derived peptide was initially introduced in 2004 [31] .

In 2015, the replacement of the VHL-targeting peptide by hydroxyproline-like small molecules J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f 6 / 23 significantly improved the affinity and specificity of the VHL-PROTAC system [32] , greatly expanding its applications. Currently, while there are over 600 known human E3 ligases, the established PROTAC systems rely on less than ten of them, of which the most widely used are CRBN [28] , Von Hippel Lindau (VHL) [31] , cIAP [24] , and MDM2 [19] discussed above.

One desiring property of PROTACs is that they catalytically involve in multiple rounds of target protein degradation [29, 32, 33] . Therefore, the degradation induced by PROTACs is sub-stoichiometric, i.e. one PROTAC molecule is able to induce the ubiquitination and degradation of multiple POI molecules. The catalytic nature of PROTACs provides potential strong degradation power with relatively low concentrations, and it is sometimes desired to have temporal and spatial control of this power. Recent studies have developed controllable PROTACs, such as photoswitchable azobenzene-PROTACs (Azo-PROTACs) and photo-caged PROTACs (pc-PROTACs) [34, 35] . Azo-PROTACs are light-controlled small-molecule tools for protein knockdown in cells. The light-induced configuration change can switch the active state to induce protein degradation activity, which can be reversely controlled by light exposure in intact cells [34] . For pc-PROTACs, photo-removable blocking groups were added to a degrader of Brd4, and the resulting molecule showed potent degradation activity in live cells only after light irradiation [35] .

While the PROTAC field is booming, a number of potential limitations of PROTAC have been identified: PROTAC molecules often have high molecular weights (over 800 Da) and relatively high polar surface area, likely leading to low solubility, poor cell permeability, low oral bioavailability as well as blood-brain barrier penetration. The PROTAC's effects are dependent on specific E3 ligase subunits and thus are influenced by their expression, limiting their application in certain cell types. The dependence on specific E3 ligase subunits may also cause resistance in cancer cells following chronic PROTAC treatment [36] . Finally, PROTAC molecules induce POIs' degradation via the proteasome, which has limited capability of proteins with expanded repeat sequences, protein aggregates, and other non-protein molecules [37] .

As discussed above, while the PROTAC technology is extremely promising, its dependence on the expression of specific E3 ligases and the proteasomal pathway may limit its potential application in certain cell types or targeting certain proteasome-resistant proteins.
body_text.section: Emerging New Concepts of Small-molecule-induced Protein Degradation

body_text.text: Encouragingly, novel concepts emerged very recently around the lysosomal degradation pathway, which is the other major degradation pathway that is independent of the proteasome [38] . The lysosomal degradation pathway includes the endosome-lysosome pathway and the autophagy pathway (reviewed in [39, 40] ). The endosome-lysosome pathway is mediate through a series of transformation between several membrane-bound intracellular compartments: the endocytosed material is incorporated and proceeds through the early endosomes, the endosome carrier vesicle, the late endosome and the lysosome for subsequent hydrolysis [39] . The autophagy pathway starts with an isolated membrane structure called a phagophore, which is derived from lipid bilayer with lipidated LC3 proteins [41] . This phagophore expands to engulf intracellular cargoes (autophagy substrates), including proteins and other biomolecules or even organelles, thereby sequestering them in a double-membraned vesicle called the autophagosome [40] . The loaded autophagosome matures through fusion with the lysosome, leading to degradation of the cargoes.
body_text.section: Emerging New Concepts of Small-molecule-induced Protein Degradation

body_text.text: Thus, both the endosome-lysosome pathway and the autophagy pathway have degradation capabilities, and new concepts have been designed and demonstrated to harness each of these pathways for selective degradation.
body_text.section: Emerging New Concepts of Small-molecule-induced Protein Degradation

body_text.text: The LYTAC (LYsosome TArgeting Chimera) technology is a promising strategy to hijack the endosome-lysosome pathway to degrade POIs, currently published as a preprint paper without peer review [42] . Excitingly, LYTAC molecules may work on extracellular proteins as well as membrane-bound proteins such as EGFR [42] . These types of proteins are typically resistant to PROTAC, which mainly targets intracellular proteins. An LYTAC molecule consists of an antibody to a specific POI, with a 20-or 90-mer of mannose-6-phosphate (M6P) covalently attached to this antibody. M6P is a glycan mark to target proteins for degradation by binding to J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f 8 / 23 the cation-independent M6P receptor (CI-M6PR) [42] . Thus, the M6P-conjugated antibodies, i.e. the LYTAC molecules, are recognized by this endogenous system for lysosomal degradation of glycosylated proteins, bring the POIs together with them to the lysosome for degradation. In certain cases, the M6P-conjugated antibodies could be replaced by CI-M6PR's polypeptide ligands conjugated to a small molecule binding to the POI. The authors confirmed that a polypeptide with multiple ligands for CI-M6PR attached to biotin (a high affinity binder to Avidin) targets the extracellular NeutrAvidin protein to the endosomes and lysosomes [42] . The advantage of the LYTAC technology is that it enables degradation of both extracellular and membrane POIs, and it utilizes a ubiquitously expressed endogenous degradation pathway. The major limitation is that LYTAC molecules are quite large, and thus lose the desired properties of small-molecule compound drugs. The antibody or polypeptide nature of the molecules may also induce immune responses [43] .
body_text.section: Emerging New Concepts of Small-molecule-induced Protein Degradation

body_text.text: The LYTAC technology targets extracellular and/or membrane POIs to the endosomelysosome pathway, and it is inapplicable for cytosolic proteins, which could be the targets of autophagy. Thus, the autophagy-targeting degrader technologies are highly desired for cytosolic POIs, especially those resistant to PROTAC molecules. While there are several different types of autophagy, it typically refers to macroautophagy, a multistep cellular process in which cargo proteins are engulfed into autophagosomes formed by intracellular double-membranes containing lipidated LC3 proteins [41] . Meanwhile, autophagy receptors such as SQSTM1/p62 may recognize Lys63 (K63) poly-ubiquitinated protein cargoes and shuttle them to autophagosomes for subsequent clearance [44] , and this process is referred to as "selective autophagy" [45, 46] . Two independent new degrader technologies harnessing the autophagy pathway have been reported very recently.
body_text.section: Emerging New Concepts of Small-molecule-induced Protein Degradation

body_text.text: The autophagy-targeting chimera (AUTAC) system utilizes a similar design as the PROTAC technology [47] . Both AUTAC and PROTAC molecules function via ubiquitination.
body_text.section: Emerging New Concepts of Small-molecule-induced Protein Degradation

body_text.text: However, instead of tethering the POIs to an E3 ligase subunit and triggering K48-poly-J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f 9 / 23 ubiquitination, AUTAC molecules trigger K63-poly-ubiquitination, which is recognized by the selective autophagy pathway to degrade the target POIs. An AUTAC molecule contains a degradation tag (guanine derivatives) and a ligand of the POI to provide target specificity. The degradation tag mimics S-Guanylation, a posttranslational modification of Cys-cGMP adducts formed by treatment of 8-nitro-cGMP or similar compounds [48] . The authors suggest that S-Guanylation is a standalone tag that destines the substrate protein for selective autophagy by inducing its K63-poly-ubiquitination [47] . The authors showed encouraging results that AUTAC molecules are capable of degrading POIs as well as cellular organelles such as damaged mitochondria.
body_text.section: Emerging New Concepts of Small-molecule-induced Protein Degradation

body_text.text: The design of AUTAC cleverly utilizes a process that defends cells against invading group A Streptococcus [49] . Meanwhile, AUTAC molecules function through a complicated multiple-step processes that need to be further clarified. In particular, the molecular mechanism mediating the S-Guanylation triggered K63-ubiquitination of POIs needs to be resolved, and the efficiency and potential off-target effects of this pathway needs to be determined. This information is required to clarify which proteins are required for the AUTAC system, how the AUTAC system may be influenced by each mediator, and whether hijacking this pathway may cause changes of other cellular functions. In addition, whether AUTAC molecules may influence the selective autophagy process per se and whether they are functional in vivo need to be investigated.
body_text.section: Emerging New Concepts of Small-molecule-induced Protein Degradation

body_text.text: The concept of autophagosome-tethering compound (ATTEC) illustrates a more direct strategy to harness autophagy to degrade POIs [50, 51] . Different from PROTAC and AUTAC, ATTEC molecules are independent of ubiquitination. Instead, ATTEC molecules tether the POI with the autophagosomes through their direct binding to the POI and the key autophagosome protein LC3. The proof-of-concept study established a high-throughput screening strategy to identify such compounds targeting the mutant HTT protein (mHTT), which is the Huntington's disease-(HD-) causing protein with an expanded polyglutamine (polyQ) stretch [52] . The study J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f 10 / 23 demonstrated that these compounds can degrade mHTT both in cells and in vivo in the animal models, and can rescue HD-relevant phenotypes [51] . The study also confirmed that these compounds can target mHTT to the autophagsomes for subsequent degradation without influencing the autophagy activity per se. By the counter-screen against binders of the wild-type HTT protein (wtHTT), the discovered ATTEC molecules are allele-selective, i.e., they degrade mHTT without influencing the wtHTT level. In vitro experiments revealed that these compounds specifically interact with the expanded polyQ stretch, possibly by recognizing its unique structural feature that is different from short polyQ stretch [53, 54] . Thus, the discovered ATTEC molecules are also capable of degrading other disease-causing polyQ proteins, such as mutant ATXN3, which causes spinocerebellar ataxia type III [51] . Some of the discovered ATTEC molecules are able to pass the blood-brain barrier and function at ~100 nM concentrations [51] , providing encouraging entry points for drug discovery. By interacting with the autophagosome protein LC3 directly and bypassing the ubiquitination process, ATTEC molecules may have great potential in degrading different types of cargoes, including autophagy-recognized non-protein cargoes such as DNA/RNA molecules, damaged organelles, etc., via a direct mechanism. ATTEC molecules do not influence global autophagy activity [51] , whereas it remains to be elucidated if AUTACs do. It is important not to perturb global autophagy, because this may minimize nonspecific degradation of functional proteins and organelles.
body_text.section: Emerging New Concepts of Small-molecule-induced Protein Degradation

body_text.text: Further studies are desired to further develop ATTEC. The compound compartments that interact with LC3 remain to be resolved for ATTEC molecules. Unlike PROTAC, LYTAC, and AUTAC, the discovered ATTEC molecules targeting mHTT have very small sizes compared to the relatively large chimeric compounds with a linker between two separate chemical moieties that interact with the POI and the degradation machinery, respectively. Whether they could be developed to functional chimeric molecules by attaching the LC3-binding "warhead" to POIs'
body_text.section: Emerging New Concepts of Small-molecule-induced Protein Degradation

body_text.text: binding compounds remains to be tested. On the other hand, these small compounds may have the advantage of having better drug properties.
body_text.section: Emerging New Concepts of Small-molecule-induced Protein Degradation

body_text.text: The emerging new concepts of degrader technologies, especially those novel ones around the autophagic/lysosomal degradation pathway may greatly expand the landscape of the applications of degrader technologies. While current studies were mainly focusing on pathogenic proteins, these new concepts could also be explored for their capabilities to degrade pathogenic targets other than soluble proteins, such as protein aggregates, DNA/RNA molecules, peroxisomes, ribosomes, damaged mitochondria or even microbial pathogens. Here we briefly discuss the future possibilities of using these concepts to degrade some of these targets as potential examples of future applications of these technologies.

Many neurodegenerative diseases, including Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's disease, and Huntington's disease, are associated with the formation of protein aggregates/oligomers by misfolded proteins [55, 56] . Clearing these protein aggregates/oligomers without affecting their wild-type counterparts is likely a promising drug discovery paradigm. Given the poor capability of the proteasome in degrading these aggregates/oligomers [37] , autophagy hijacking degraders may have a better capability to target protein aggregates for selective degradation, at least in theory. Consistent with this, one of the discovered ATTEC molecules reduced mutant HTT aggregates significantly [51] . Given that most of the relevant diseases are neurological, the molecules with high lipid solubility and a molecular weight under 500 Da are desired, because they are expected to have a higher chance to cross the blood-brain barrier via passive diffusion [57] . Thus, degraders with smaller molecular weights may have better chance to be developed into drug candidates for the treatment of neurodegeneration. Interestingly, Tau degrader was J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f recently reported based on the PROTAC system [58] . The compounds efficiently degraded neurodegeneration-related soluble Tau protein, but the Tau aggregates/tangles were not tested [58] . These Tau species might be degraded more efficiently by emerging lysosome-based technologies. Neurodegenerative disorders may also lead to altered lysosome-related functions.

Taking Huntington's disease as an example, the mainstream evidence showed increased presence of endocytic and autophagic compartments [59] [60] [61] [62] and reduced cargo/mHTT recognition [54, [63] [64] [65] . This further justifies enhancing the recognition of pathogenic proteins by degrader technologies such as ATTEC. Meanwhile, for certain diseases with severe lysosomal deficits, correcting the lysosomal function per se is probably more important.

The RNA molecules could be directly recognized by a lysosomal membrane protein, LAMP2C, which load them into the lysosomes for degradation [66] . Further studies revealed that a putative RNA transporter SIDT2 mediates the RNA translocation across the lysosomal membrane [67, 68] . Thus, scientists may screen for high-affinity binding molecules of LAMP2C or SIDT2 and attach them to antisense oligonucleotides or small molecules specifically binding to the target RNA. These chimeric molecules may selectively degrade the target RNA and knock down its encoded pathogenic proteins. This may provide a novel degrader technology for RNA, in addition to the recent nuclease-targeting RNA degrader technology developed by the Disney group [69] . For the DNA molecules, the clearance of cytosolic DNA molecules under pathological conditions is highly desired. Cyclic GMP-AMP (cGAMP) synthase (cGAS) detects infections or tissue damage by binding to microbial or self DNA in the cytoplasm [70] . Upon binding to the DNA, cGAS produces cGAMP that binds to and activates the adaptor protein STING [71] , which induces LC3 lipidation and activates autophagy [72] . The cGAMP-induced autophagy is critical for the clearance of DNA and viruses in the cytosol [72] . This provides a promising possibility of using the autophagy-targeting degrader technologies to enhance the clearance of these DNA molecules and their relevant pathogens or damaged cellular components.

Since the cytosolic DNA could not be ubiquitinated, the suitable degrader technology here is J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f 13 / 23 probably ATTEC. Scientists may use the ATTEC concept to design molecules consisting of the target DNA binding molecule attached to the LC3-binding chemical moiety, and these chimeric ATTEC molecules may tether the DNA to LC3 for subsequent autophagic degradation.

Bacterial and viral infections present a severe global threat to healthcare. While the antibiotics treatment has obtained enormous success, new therapeutic approaches are desired due to the rise of antibiotic-resistant infections and the dearth of new antibiotics in the pipeline [73] .

Selective autophagy is the major intracellular pathway that targets intracellular pathogens to lysosomes for degradation, and the process is referred to as xenophagy [74] . Thus, autophagylysosome degrader technologies such as ATTEC or AUTAC could be used to target key proteins of the pathogen, leading to enhanced clearance of them via xenophagy. This approach may provide synergistic effects with xenophagy enhancement approaches that have been studied recently to control bacterial infection [75] . Another potential strategy is to target the microbial DNA/RNA to autophagic degradation by ATTEC as discussed in the previous paragraph. The pathogen COVID-19 responsible for the recent pneumonia outbreak could be targeted by the design above as well [76] (see "Outstanding Questions"). Meanwhile, many pathogens have evolved ways to subvert or exploit this defense mechanism, minimizing the actual effectiveness of xenophagy in innate immunity [73, 77] . A better understanding of the complicated relationship between autophagy and microbial pathogens will provide better opportunities to combine novel degrader technologies with xenophagy enhancement approaches to achieve optimal therapeutic effects.
Emerging new concepts of degrader technologies have been designed to harness the relatively non-specific lysosomal degradation pathway for selective degradation of the POIs.

These concepts greatly expand the landscape of therapeutic targets and provide exciting novel approaches of potential therapeutic benefits. LYTACs utilize a glycan tag to mark extracellular POI for intracellular lysosomal degradation following receptor mediated internalization. AUTACs cleverly exploit small-molecule mimics of S-Guanylation to selectively tag POI with K63 ubiquitination and induce their lysosomal degradation via selective autophagy. On the other hand, ATTECs exploit lipidated LC3 to directly tether polyQ proteins to growing autophagosomes to facilitate their selective removal via autophagy. Meanwhile, they have critical concerns to be addressed before maturing to established technologies.

The specificity and potential off-target effects need to be clarified for these technologies (see "Outstanding Questions"). Proteomics studies have been performed for ATTEC in cellular and tissue samples [51] , while such studies for LYTAC and AUTAC are currently missing.

Besides the proteomics studies measuring the steady-state protein levels, researchers may consider investigating whether the compounds interact with proteins other than their designated targets. Scientists may pull-down the compound-binding proteins in cell or tissue lysates and perform proteomics analysis of the pull-down samples to reveal their potential off-target binding partners. In addition, whether these technologies are catalytic and may function substoichiometrically need to be clarified (see Outstanding Questions). In theory, AUTAC and ATTEC could be catalytic because the small molecules such as AUTAC and ATTEC could be recycled after lysosomal degradation of the target proteins, but this needs to be further tested and validated. LYTAC molecules are likely non-catalytic because of its current large biomolecular nature. The non-catalytic nature of the compounds' function may lead to less efficient and yet more controllable degradation compared to catalytic technologies.

There are also specific concerns to be addressed for each of these emerging technologies (see Outstanding Questions). The large LYTAC molecules are desired to be reduced to small molecules for easier delivery and prevention of immune responses. To achieve this, scientists may identify small molecules binding to CI-M6PR by screening or structure-based design. The addressed by interactome studies for protein recognizing this modification, or biochemical screening for modifiers of S-guanylation-induced K63-poly-ubiquitination. The potential influence on autophagy by AUTAC also needs to be tested. Compared to LYTAC and AUTAC studies, the biological effects of ATTEC molecules have been investigated relatively thoroughly.

Meanwhile, the atomic level structural information for the compound-protein interfaces is critical for ATTEC and remains to be solved. Chimeric ATTEC molecules also need to be designed and (B) The schematic illustration of AUTAC. AUTACs bind to the POI and add a degradation tag mimicking S-Guanylation, a posttranslational modification that triggers the K63-polyubiquitination of POI. The POI is then recognized by the autophagy receptor SQSTM1/p62 protein and recruited to the selective autophagy pathway for degradation. For the AUTAC molecule, the "G" pentagon represents the chemical moiety mimicking S-Guanylation and the linked pacman shape represents the targeting recognizing part.
(C) The schematic illustration of ATTEC. ATTECs interact with both the POI and LC3, tethering the POI to the phagophores or autophagosomes directly for subsequent autophagic degradation.

FIGREF1.text: summary, besides the PROTAC technology or its further development, at least three emerging new concepts of degrader technologies have been demonstrated recently (Figure 2, Key Figure). While each of these new concepts has its advantages and limitations (Table 1), they have greatly expanded the potential applications of degrader technologies and may open new avenues of research in the field of targeted degradation.

FIGREF3.text: CI-M6PR-binding small molecule may then replace the long M6P chain or CI-M6PR polypeptide ligand to reduce the size of LYTACs. For AUTAC, the mechanism of action is still unclear, especially how S-guanylation induces K63-poly-ubiquitination. This could potentially be J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f 15 / 23

FIGREF4.text: emerging degrader technologies have key concerns to be addressed, they are at the infancy and have unprecedented potentials. With appropriate efforts in the right direction, they may greatly expand the target spectrum of degrader technologies and develop into exciting new avenues of research.

FIGREF5.text: Schematic models of established strategies to selectively lower the protein of interest (POI) (A) The schematic illustration of the DNA and RNA targeting technologies such as genome editing (represented by a pair of scissors cutting the target DNA) or antisense oligonucleotides (ASOs) that induce the target RNA degradation and protein translation inhibition. (B) The schematic illustration of the hydrophobic tagging (HyT) technology, which adds a hydrophobic tag onto the POIs to induce their degradation via the proteasome directly, independent of E3 ligases and ubiquitination. (C) The schematic illustration of the four major PROTAC systems utilizing the indicated E3 ligase subunits. The PROTAC molecules bring the POIs in proximity to the corresponding E3 ligases to facilitate POI's K48-poly-ubiquitination, leading to their subsequent degradation via the proteasome. All the molecules were drawn based on public PDB files (CRBN-PROTAC-BRD4 (PDB: 6BN7); VHL-PROTAC-BRD4 (PDB: 5T35); cIAP1(PDB: 3UW4), CRABP2 (PDB: 3CBS); MDM2 (PDB: 4HF2), AR (PDB: 1XOW); Ub: (PDB: 5GOI); HyT POI: DHFR (PDB: 5UII); Proteasome:(PDB: 4CR2)). The PDB files of the cIAP and MDM2 PROTAC complexes were unavailable, and thus their PROTAC molecules were represented by cartoon shapes.

FIGREF6.text: Key Figure. Schematic models emerging degrader technologies (A) The schematic illustration of LYTAC. LYTACs utilize a glycan tag to mark extracellular POIfor intracellular lysosomal degradation following receptor mediated internalization. Note that the LYTAC paper has not been peer reviewed and formally published yet.
